criteria.title: PEA-S8: Provide Physical Education
criteria.criterionText: Our school provides physical education in all grades, and prohibits waivers, exemptions, and substitutions for physical education class time or credit (except for accommodations made for students with medical, cultural, or religious considerations).

questions.text: Does your school provide physical education classes?
Which grade levels receive physical education at your school?
Can students waive, be exempted from, or substitute other activities for physical education class time or credit?
Under what circumstances can students waive, be exempted from, or substitute for physical education?
options: Participation in other sports or activities

required.description: Q047 includes all grade levels present at the school.
Q048 is "No" OR Q049 only includes medical, cultural, or religious considerations.

criteria.title: PEA-S9: Physical Education Curriculum
criteria.criterionText: Our school requires all physical education teachers to use a curriculum that is developmentally appropriate, culturally responsive, sequential, and consistent with national or state standards for physical education.

questions.text: Do physical education teachers at your school use a defined curriculum?
Which of the following characteristics describe your school's physical education curriculum?
options: Developmentally appropriate (designed to meet the needs of students at different developmental stages)
Culturally responsive (reflects and respects diverse cultural backgrounds)
Sequential (builds skills progressively across grade levels)
Consistent with national or state standards for physical education

questions.text: Are all physical education teachers required to use this curriculum?
How does your school ensure the curriculum is implemented consistently?
options: Regular professional development for PE teachers
Curriculum guides or lesson plans provided
Observations or evaluations of PE classes
We do not have a formal process

required.description: Q051 includes all four characteristics (developmentally appropriate, culturally responsive, sequential, and consistent with standards).
Q052 is "Yes."
Q053 includes at least 1 method (not 'We do not have a formal process').

criteria.title: PEA-S11: Physical Activity During the School Day
criteria.criterionText: All students are provided opportunities to engage in at least 30 cumulative minutes of physical activity during each school day (e.g., recess, physical activity breaks, active instruction). Note: Physical activity minutes do not include physical education or class transitions.

questions.text: Do students at your school have opportunities for physical activity during the school day outside of physical education classes?
What types of physical activity opportunities are provided during the school day?
Approximately how many cumulative minutes of physical activity (outside of PE class) do students typically get during each school day?
Are these physical activity opportunities available to all students?

required.description: Q055 includes at least 1 type of physical activity.
Q056 is "30-44 minutes", "45-59 minutes", or "60 minutes or more."
Q057 is "Yes."

criteria.title: PEA-S13: Physical Activity and Disciplinary Practices
criteria.criterionText: Our school prohibits staff from assigning physical activity as punishment (e.g., walking laps or doing pushups) and prohibits staff from withholding physical activity as punishment (e.g., withholding recess, physical activity breaks, or physical education class).

questions.text: Does your school have a policy or practice regarding the use of physical activity in disciplinary situations?
Which of the following statements describe your school's policy or practice?
options: Staff are prohibited from assigning physical activity as punishment (e.g., making students walk laps or do pushups)
Staff are prohibited from withholding recess as punishment
Staff are prohibited from withholding physical activity breaks as punishment
Staff are prohibited from withholding physical education class as punishment
Staff may use physical activity as punishment in some situations
Staff may withhold physical activity as punishment in some situations

questions.text: How is this policy communicated to staff?
options: Included in staff handbook or policy manual
Discussed during staff orientation or onboarding

questions.text: How does your school ensure compliance with this policy?
options: We do not have a formal process

required.description: Q059 includes all four prohibitions (assigning PA as punishment, withholding recess, withholding PA breaks, withholding PE class).
Q060 includes at least 1 communication method (not 'It is not formally communicated').
Q061 includes at least 1 compliance mechanism (not 'We do not have a formal process').

criteria.title: PEA-S14: School Facilities Open to Community
criteria.criterionText: Our school's indoor and outdoor facilities (e.g., tracks, playgrounds, athletic fields, gymnasiums, classrooms) are open to students, families, caregivers, and community members outside of school hours.

questions.text: Are your school's facilities available for use outside of regular school hours?
Which facilities are available for community use outside of school hours?
Who can access these facilities outside of school hours?
When are facilities available for community use?
How is information about facility availability communicated to the community?

required.description: Q063 includes at least 1 facility type.
Q064 includes 'General community members' (open to broader community, not just school families).
Q065 includes at least 1 time period.
Q066 includes at least 1 communication method (not 'It is not actively communicated').

criteria.title: PEA-S15: Collaborate with Community to Support Physical Activity
criteria.criterionText: Our school's process for collaborating with community organizations includes implementing shared goals, defined roles and responsibilities, ongoing communication, and evaluation plans.

questions.text: Does your school collaborate with community organizations to support physical activity for students?
Which types of community organizations does your school collaborate with for physical activity?
Which of the following elements are part of your collaboration process with community organizations?
options: Shared goals (we've identified common objectives together)
Defined roles and responsibilities (we're clear about who does what)
Ongoing communication (we have regular check-ins or updates)
Evaluation plans (we assess the effectiveness of the collaboration)

questions.text: How often does your school communicate with community partners about physical activity collaborations?
options: As needed/not on a regular schedule

questions.text: What types of physical activity opportunities result from these collaborations?
options: Special events (fun runs, sports days, etc.)
Coaching or instruction from community partners

required.description: Q068 includes at least 1 type of community organization.
Q069 includes all four elements (shared goals, defined roles, ongoing communication, evaluation plans).
Q071 includes at least 1 type of physical activity opportunity.

criteria.title: PEA-S16: Active Transportation Initiatives
criteria.criterionText: Our school supports active transportation initiatives through engaging the school community, ensuring equitable and inclusive opportunities to participate, designating safe routes or preferred routes, providing events/activities/programs, educating students to walk and bicycle safely, and evaluating the initiatives.

questions.text: Does your school support active transportation initiatives (e.g., walk to school, bike to school programs)?
How does your school engage the school community in active transportation initiatives?
options: Surveys or input sessions with families and students
We do not actively engage the community

questions.text: How does your school ensure equitable and inclusive opportunities for students to participate in active transportation?
options: Consider barriers different families may face
Provide resources or support (e.g., bikes, helmets)
Create walking school bus or bike trains for safety
Offer alternatives for students who can't walk/bike
Gather feedback from diverse family groups
We have not specifically addressed equity and inclusion

questions.text: Has your school designated safe routes or preferred routes for students walking or biking?
What events, activities, or programs does your school provide related to active transportation?
options: Regular walk/bike challenges or incentive programs

questions.text: How does your school educate students about walking and bicycling safely?
options: We do not provide safety education

questions.text: How does your school evaluate your active transportation initiatives?
options: Review and adjust strategies based on data

required.description: Q073 includes at least 1 engagement method (not 'We do not actively engage the community').
Q074 includes at least 1 equity/inclusion strategy (not 'We have not specifically addressed equity and inclusion').
Q075 is "Yes."
Q076 includes at least 1 event/activity/program (not 'None').
Q077 includes at least 1 safety education method (not 'We do not provide safety education').
Q078 includes at least 1 evaluation method (not 'We do not formally evaluate').
